document.docOrigin: Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society 162 (2)
document.docTitle: Pseudocorinna alligator Jocqué & Bosselaers 2011, SP. NOV.
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of Pseudocorinna Simon and a new related genus (Araneae: Corinnidae): two more examples of spider templates with a large range of complexity in the genitalia

caption.paragraph:
Figure 9.
Pseudocorinna alligator
sp. nov.
, male holotype (MRAC 151630) (A–C) and female paratype (MRAC 202399) (D–F), and
Pseudocorinna amicorum
sp. nov.
, female holotype (MRAC 162110) (G, H). A, B, right male palp, ventral and retrolateral views; C, left male palpal tibia, prolateral view; D, E, epigyne, ventral and posterior views; F, cleared epigyne, dorsal view; G, epigyne, ventral view; H, cleared epigyne, dorsal view. Scale bars: A–C = 1 mm; D–H = 0.5 mm. CAPT, central apophysis of posterior part of tegulum; E, embolus; FC, functional conductor; MA, median apophysis.

Diagnosis: Males of
P. alligator
are easily recognized by the massive MA and FC as well as by the shape of the RTA. Females are recognized by the shape of the dark delimitation of the posterior epigyne margin and the details of the internal structure.
Etymology: The species name is a noun in apposition and refers to the RTA outline resembling the profile of the head of an alligator.
Description: Male ( holotype , MRAC 151630). Total l 5.40.

Carapace chestnut brown, covered by tiny warts forming a network with polygonal meshes. Carapace l: 2.65; w: 2.10. Fovea deep, clearly delimited. Sternum warted, l: 1.15; w: 1.30. Chelicerae, pleural bars, endites, labium, and chilum covered by fine warts. Abdomen greyish brown, with a large, brown do scutum covering 90% of do abdominal surface area.
Legs orange-brown, covered by fine warts.

Male palp ( Fig. 9A–C ): RTA outline resembling the profile of the head of an alligator with long pointed inferior part; PTA simple, triangular. Embolus tiny, spine shaped, hidden by frontal excrescence of proximal part of tegulum. FC originating at base of embolus, curved out- and backward, encircling MA which is massive, almost reaching tip of cymbium, with membranous appendage at base. Proximal part of tegulum with frontal part triangular and rounded at extremity. PAPT broad, pointing outward. RAPT absent.

Carapace as in male, l: 2.55; w: 2.10. Sternum warted, l: 1.15; w: 1.30. Chelicerae, pleural bars, endites, labium, and chilum as in male. Abdomen greyish brown, without do scutum. Legs orangebrown, covered by fine warts.

Epigyne ( Figs 9D–F , 38A ): fairly simple with poorly defined broad plate with two small bulges near posterior margin; copulatory openings lateral, in front; short curved copulatory ducts lead to convoluted spermathecae; fertilization ducts strongly developed.
Known geographical distribution: Guinea , Liberia , Ivory Coast ( Fig. 18 ).
